column1: 2019AGUFM.P33C..06S|2019|Apollo 17's Deep Drill Core 70001/9 δ<SUP>15</SUP>N Data Indicates A Factor Of 1.7 Increase The Rate Of Regolith Maturation 500 ± 200 Myr Ago Because Of An Increase In Solar Luminosity That Also May Have Triggered The Cambrian Explosion.|Schmitt
column2: H. H.|AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|2019||P33C-06|Apollo 11's Field Geology Experiment team included small core tubes for use on the first lunar landing 50 years ago. The rationale for coring on this and other missions rested primarily on the hypothesis that development of the regolith would have recorded the history of the solar wind and the flux and composition of meteors and comets impacting the Moon. The most complete core is the 298 cm Apollo 17 deep drill core 70001/9 and a synthesis of geologic
column3: petrographic and geochemical data from numerous papers (published 1974-2017) produced the following conclusions: 70001/9 consists of nine major regolith units
column4: based on differences in maturity indexes
column6: and particle size- and type-frequency. The nine units probably span at least 1 billion years of solar system history. Primary indicators of maturity of each unit (Is/FeO
column9: and agglutinate percent) are highly correlated. After deposition
column10: the surface of each unit was disturbed by small impacts
column11: defined by reductions in Is/FeO. The second highest unit correlates petrographically and chemically with600-meter diameter Camelot Crater (rim 1 km away)
column12: estimated by topographic diffusion analysis to be 500 ± 200 Myr old. Several units in the core can be correlated with ejecta from impact craters within the valley of Taurus-Littrow morphologically older than Camelot. δ<SUP>15</SUP>Nat specific points in the lower 7 units of 70001/9 increases linearly with Is/FeOwith a slope of +1.22 δ<SUP>15</SUP>N‰ per Is/FeO point increase. Correcting δ<SUP>15</SUP>N‰ in the lower 7 units for their maturity gives a consistent solar wind δ<SUP>15</SUP>N value of -105 ± 5‰ at their times of deposition. The top two core units
column14:
require an increase in the rate of maturation to +2.07δ15N‰ per Is/FeO point to equal a solar wind δ15N value of -105 ± 5‰.

Assuming no change in solar wind δ15N‰
column15:
this synthesis of data on 70001/9 indicates that the Sun's luminosity would have increased by a factor of about 1.7 about 500 million years ago. Could this solar warming have triggered the Cambrian Explosion of life's quantity and diversity on Earth 540 million years ago?

Plans for future coring on the Moon should include deep cores that reach to the entire depth of regolith now present on dated mare and basin ejecta.|

column1: 1982LPSC...12..519N|1982|An ancient avalanche deposit in the Taurus-Littrow Valley is part of the long depositional history of the Apollo 17 drill core.|Nagle
column2: J. S.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|12||519|A description is presented of data and new calculations which support the idea that the Apollo 17 drill string has a long depositional history. Attention is given to a new interpretation
column3: that a very ancient avalanche was a major depositional event in the history of the core. Important implications for composition of soil components then result from the avalanche interpretation. It is pointed out that single-slab deposition of the entire Apollo 17 drill string would require some extremely unusual events
column4: including preferential disappearance of a 75-150 m crater
column5: and redeposition of 11 oriented features in an upright
column6: instead of the normal overturned position. It appears to be more likely that the oldest valley floor surface is the basalt-rich zone below 275 cm.|

column1: 1980LPSC...11.1395L|1980|The Apollo 17 drill core: chemistry of size fractions and the nature of the fused soil component.|Laul
column4: J. J.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1395|It is shown that the Apollo 17 drill core 70009-70001 is heterogeneous with depth
column6: and has a bulk soil chemistry governed by the coarse fractions because of their greater weight proportions. The four components (1) KREEP
column9: and (4) orange glass are used to model the compositions of the coarse and fine fractions of the entire drill core. It is found that the chemistry of the fused soil component in the five stratigraphic units is more similar to the chemistry of the fine
column10: less than 20-micron fractions than the coarse fraction
column11: suggesting that agglutinates may prefferentially meld and replicate the chemistry of the finer size fractions. The sources of Zn are the orange/black glasses
column12: and the Zn profile is anticorrelated with the maturity index of Morris et al (1979)
column13: indicating the liberation of Zn during soil maturation.|

column1: 1980LPSC...11.1497E|1980|Recent depositional history of Apollo 16 and 17 cores.|Evans
column10: R. W.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1497|Measurements of Al-26 and Mn-53 in the Apollo 17 drive tube 76001 show a clear integral excess of activity above expected production down to a depth of at least 9 gm/sq cm. This excess is interpreted as a continuous accretion of highly irradiated surface material slowly transported downslope by impact or other processes at a buildup rate of 1.5 cm/m.y. This drive tube
column12: was collected near a change in slope on the North Massif. Integral excesses have also been observed in other Apollo 16 and 17 cores. Evidence in the Al-26 and Mn-53 record for continuous accretion is shown for Apollo 16 cores 60007 and 60010 and the Apollo 16 deep drill string 70009-70001. This evaluation shows that accretion at specific sites
column13: either through continuous downslope movement or regolith material on the moon
column14: or simply through small impact redistribution
column15: is common on both small and large scales.|

column6: S. R.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1463|The paper presents depth scales in cm from the surface
column7: and overburden mass in g/cu cm for Apollo 15
column10: which are based on original sample data
column12: and flight hardware. The Apollo 15 drill core was completely filled
column13: with a straightforward scale accurately representing in situ lunar conditions. A large void in the Apollo 16 drill core was found
column14: although there is evidence that only the upper half of the core has been disturbed. Voids were also found in the upper part of the Apollo 17 drill core
column15: which are explained by sample migration in the tube
column16: and thus the scale for the core closely represents in situ lunar conditions|

column4: J.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1609|Twelve polished thin sections from Apollo 17 drive tube 76001 have been studied by optical petrography. The entire core is found to be mature showing little variation in depth
column5: which is consistent with a depositional model involving slow downslope movement of the regolith by mass wasting. However
column6: within the core some major differences are preserved between two stratigraphic units. Unit A (20-31 cm depth) is enriched in gabbroic anorthosite relative to unit B (0-20 cm depth)
column7: while unit B is enriched in KREEPY noritic breccias relative to unit A. This observation is interpreted in terms of a stratigraphy for North Massif involving a noritic breccia unit overlying a unit enriched in gabbroic anorthosite. Pronounced differences between the highland/mare ratios in drive tube 76001 and the Apollo 17 drill core separated by only 3.5 km demonstrate the relative inefficiency of lateral transport as a regolith mixing mechanism on the moon.|

column1: 1980LPSC...11.1415L|1980|The depositional history of the Apollo 17 deep drill core: a reappraisal.|Langevin
column4: J. S.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1415|Such Apollo 17 core sedimentology results as the identification of crater bottom deposits allow the rejection of this core's hypothesized deposition in a single event 100 million years ago
column5: in light of a reassessment of all available experimental evidence. A more complex depositional history consistent with cosmogenic exposure ages
column7: which involves major cratering events as well as depositional ones over a period of more than one billion years
column8: has been independently proposed by Langevin and Maurette (1978) and Nagle and Waltz (1979).|

column1: 1979LPSC...10.1253G|1979|Depositional history of the Apollo 17 deep drill core based on particle track records.|Goswami
column4: D.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1253|Eighty samples from various depths of the 3-meter Apollo 17 deep drill core are analyzed using the particle track method. The track data indicate that the depositional history of the core has a time scale of 500-600 million years and is composed of a series of depositional sequences involving both slow and fast accretion as well as removal of material due to erosion events. Track parameters show a systematic trend as a function of depth: low values are observed at depths 20-70
column7: 225-250 and 285 cm with high values in between
column8: which corresponds to a repetition depth of 0.5 m. The observed variations correlate with agglutinate and FMR data.|

column1: 1979LPSC...10.1141M|1979|Characterization and depositional and evolutionary history of the Apollo 17 deep drill core.|Morris
column7: W. A.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1141|With a depth resolution of about 0.5 cm
column8: the stratigraphy of the approximately 3 m Apollo 17 deep drill core by measurement of the total FeO concentration is characterized along with the FMR surface exposure (maturity) index Is/FeO
column10: and the FMR linewidth delta-H. For stratigraphic characterization
column11: the first two parameters are the most important. Most of the core is characterized by a FeO concentration of approximately 15.5 wt. %; there is a more mafic zone in the upper approximately 75 cm where the maximum FeO concentration is approximately 18.5 wt. %
column12: and a more felsic zone between approximately 225 and 260 cm where the minimum FeO concentration is approximately 14.0%. As indicated by Is/FeO
column13: most of the soil in the core is submature to mature; the only immature zone is located between approximately 20 and 60 cm and is one of the most distinctive features in the core. A two stage model for the depositional and evolutionary history of the Apollo 17 deep drill core is proposed: (1) deposition by one event approximately 110 m.y. ago or deposition by a sequence of closely spaced events initating a maximum of approximately 200 m.y. ago and terminating approximately 110 m.y. ago
column14: (2) in situ reworking (gardening) to a depth of approximately 26 cm in the period between approximately 110 m.y. ago and the present day.|

column1: 1979LPSC...10.1269L|1979|The Apollo 17 drill core: chemical systematics of grain size fractions.|Laul
column8: J. J.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1269|Data for 35 major
column10: and trace elements in 40 bulk and size fractions of core 70005-70003 (140-250 cm) are presented. The core is heterogeneous with depth. Moreover
column11: the 1000 to 90 micron coarse fractions are nearly identical but quite different from the less than 20 micron fine fraction. The bulk soil chemistry is governed by the coarse fractions
column12: because of their greater weight proportion in the sample. The 1000-90 micron fraction contains more ilmenite basalt and less orange glass components than the 90-20 micron fraction. The less than 20 micron fraction is consistently enriched in highland material at all depths in the drill core.|

column1: 1978LPSC....9.1801M|1978|In situ reworking (gardening) of the lunar surface: Evidence from the Apollo cores.|Morris
column2: R. V.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1801|The in situ reworking (gardening) of the lunar surface by impacting projectiles creates an in situ reworking zone extending horizontally over the entire regolith surface and extending vertically from the surface to a depth which varies from place-to-place on the moon. On the basis of available evidence
column3: the 'high-maturity' zones observed at the top of the lunar cores have resulted from the in situ reworking of the present-day lunar surface. The temporal variation of the in situ reworking depth was investigated using depths inferred from maturity I<SUB>s/FeO</SUB> and Al-26 profiles of Apollo cores. The observed temporal variation of the in situ reworking depth in units of centimeters is equal to 2.2 times the time (in units of million years) to the 0.45th power.|

column5: M.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1765|A Monte Carlo soil mixing code (ORSOLMIX) has been used to randomly generate 200 distinct depositional histories in the lunar regolith
column6: which were then used to compute the depth of concentration profiles of four cosmic-ray-induced isotopes (Ne-21
column9: and Gd-158) up to depths of 600 g/sq cm in the lunar regolith. The principal aim of the study was to tackle the difficult problem of solving a set of integral equations from which the depositional histories of the Apollo 15
column11: and 17 core tubes could be inferred from the corresponding depth profiles so far available from these core tubes. For this purpose a 'graphical' method for finding the solutions of these equations was developed which depends on the analysis of a great number (about 2000) of features imprinted on the 200 sets of depth profiles.|
